00001 /***************************************************************************
00002         Author: Sheridan Beebe
00003         Game:   Toasted
00004         File:   driver.c
00005         Date:   January 16th, 2007
00006         Description:
00007                         This is the header file for LevelManager.c. It is to include
00008                         all prototypes and type defines, enums, structures, etc. This
00009                         file should be included by any other file that needs to access
00010                         the level management functions.
00011 ***************************************************************************/
00012 
00013 /* includes, malloc */
00014 #include <stdlib.h>
00015 #include <string.h>
00016 #include <stdio.h>

00018 /*! \brief This defines the longest line to read - makes the max x for the level 1000. */
00019 #define LONGEST_LINE 1001
00020 
00021 /*! \brief This is the number of total layers to create when loading levels. */
00022 #define LAYER_COUNT 3
00023 /* These are the layers to be used by certain items */
00024 /*! \brief This is the layer number to be used by the player. */
00025 #define PLAYER_LAYER 1
00026 /*! \brief This is the layer number to be used by the walls. */
00027 #define WALL_LAYER 0
00028 /*! \brief This is the layer number to be used by the weapons. */
00029 #define WEAPON_LAYER 2
00030 /*! \brief This is the layer number to be used by the enemies. */
00031 #define ENEMY_LAYER 1
00032 /*! \brief This is the layer number to be used by the health packs. */
00033 #define HEALTH_LAYER 0
00034 /*! \brief This is the layer number to be used by the switches. */
00035 #define SWITCH_LAYER 0
00036 
00037 /* Enums for the level manager */
00038 
00039 /*! 
00040    \brief This enum is used to identify what type of object is contained in a LEVEL_POSITION.
00041    It is type defed as POSITION_TYPE. 
00042 */
00043 enum E_POSITION_TYPE {POSITION_SPACE = 1, /*!< Defines this position as an empty space. */
00044                                                 POSITION_ENEMY, /*!< Defines this position as an enemy. */
00045                                                 POSITION_PLAYER, /*!< Defines this position as the player. */
00046                                                 POSITION_WALL, /*!< Defines this position as a wall. */
00047                                                 POSITION_HEALTH, /*!< Defines this position as a health pack. */
00048                                                 POSITION_SWITCH, /*!< Defines this position as a switch. */
00049                                                 POSITION_WEAPON /*!< Defines this position as a weapon. */
00050                                                 };
00051 
00052 /*! \brief This type is used for storing what type of object is currently in a specific position */
00053 typedef enum E_POSITION_TYPE POSITION_TYPE;
00054 
00055 /* structs to be used by the level manager */
00056 
00057 /*!
00058    \brief The level position type is a struct used to store information on each position
00059    of a map. 
00060    
00061    For instance, if there is a wall in a given location, that position
00062    will have a pointer to a LEVEL_POSITION struct for all walls. The same goes for
00063    spaces, enemies, weapons, player, what ever. 
00064 */
00065 typedef struct
00066 {
00067         /*! \brief The data pointer is a pointer to the data that is in this spot. If there is
00068            enemy at this location, it points to the particular enemy struct that is here. */
00069         void *data;
00070 
00071         /*! \brief Store what type of object is at this position */
00072         POSITION_TYPE type;
00073 
00074         /*! \brief Character that should be displayed in this position */
00075         char character;
00076 
00077 } LEVEL_POSITION;
00078 
00079 
00080 /*! 
00081    \brief This struct will be the main struct to hold a level. It will contain
00082    everything that partains to a certain level. This way we can ensure to keep
00083    everything together. Its typedef'ed as a LEVEL type. 
00084 */
00085 typedef struct 
00086 {
00087         /*! 
00088            \brief This character array will store the file name of this particular map.
00089 
00090            The file name should be relative to the application exe and less than 20
00091            chatacters. 
00092         */
00093         char fileName[20];
00094 
00095         /*! \brief This is a pointer to the very first level position in our map, ie. (0,0),
00096            the top left position. 
00097            
00098            It is used to calcuate and store all level positions on all layers. 
00099            The level positions will be layed out like so:
00100 
00101            layer 1 starting with 0, 0 to n,n<br>
00102            layer 2 starting with 0, 0 to n,n<br>
00103            layer n starting with 0, 0 to n,n.<br>
00104            This will allow for an expandable layering system if
00105            the need should arise. */
00106         LEVEL_POSITION **firstPosition;
00107 
00108         /*! \brief This holds the width of the level */
00109         int width;
00110 
00111         /*! \brief This holds the height of the level */
00112         int height;
00113 
00114 } LEVEL;
00115
